item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->The Catalan duo’s brutal post-industrial style captures the spirit of the now-legendary club it rose from, writes Skye Butchard

item.title: Georgia high school shooting: student charged with murder after four people killed in Apalachee
item.description: Authorities say suspect, 14, also wounded nine others, with FBI later saying they had investigated him and his father a year ago

item.title: Ministers introduce plans to remove all hereditary peers from Lords
item.description: Government’s bill would prevent the 92 remaining peers who inherited their titles from sitting in upper chamber

item.title: New Order to Reissue ‘Brotherhood’ in Deluxe Box Set
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> The expanded edition of the band’s 1986 album takes in unreleased demos, 12-inch singles and two DVDs

item.title: Moin Reveal New Album for AD 93, ‘You Never End’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> The 11-track release is out next month

item.title: Sade’s First New Song in Six Years to Appear on New Compilation
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> ‘Young Lion’ is dedicated to her son, Izaak, and appears on a new release celebrating trans artists and people

item.title: The Body Detail New LP, ‘The Crying Out Of Things’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> It’s out on Thrill Jockey in November

item.title: Ireland, Wales and the scholar who helped unravel their Celtic connections
item.description: Cecile O’Rahilly was responsible for groundbreaking research on the historical and literary ties between Ireland and Wales.

item.title: The UK’s suspension of some arms exports to Israel was highly political – here’s how to understand it
item.description: David Lammy is not the first Labour foreign secretary to revisit arms contracts on ethical grounds.

item.title: When did the climate crisis begin?
item.description: A new book argues that climate change rose from imperialism and capitalism.

item.title: Pro-Putin movement expands across the former Soviet bloc – here’s why
item.description: East Germans are not the only former members of the Soviet bloc who are moving closer to Putin’s position on the Ukraine war.

item.title: How stories can teach young people about life in a changing climate
item.description: Drawing on students’ personal experiences can be a helpful way of approaching climate adaptation.

item.title: Grenfell Tower report: an expert explains why so many people have been blamed
item.description: The inquiry accused companies of misleading the market to make cladding products seem safer than they were known to be.

item.title: Grenfell victims were ‘overcome by toxic gases’ – this is the deadly construction loophole that helped cause their deaths
item.description: Manufacturers have to provide information on the fire behaviour of construction products, but there is no requirement to quantify the toxicity of the smoke.

item.title: Licking an ice lolly at school might make a good memory – but this isn’t the secret to learning science
item.description: If you stop to think about it, most of your knowledge can’t be clearly tied to one particular experience.

item.title: As hair transplants become big business, here’s what you need to know about the risks
item.description: Hair today, gone tomorrow? Not with the latest transplant procedures – but what are the risks?

item.title: Oasis tickets: how dynamic pricing works – and how touts may have driven up prices
item.description: It’s a question of supply and demand – but does that make it fair?

item.title: Pearson Sound Unveils New EP on Hessle Audio, ‘Which Way Is Up’
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> The four-tracker is the UK producer’s first EP since 2022

item.description: The post <!-- raw HTML omitted -->In Photos: Blooming Bedminster<!-- raw HTML omitted --> appeared first on <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Bristol24/7<!-- raw HTML omitted -->.

item.title: After the crowdfunder: how can cultural spaces not just survive, but thrive?
item.description: In Bristol and elsewhere, campaigns to safeguard arts venues’ future are commonplace – and regularly smash fundraising targets. But the hard work doesn’t stop there.

item.title: 10 Questions: Dan Norris – ‘It is vital public transport in Bristol and across the West of England improves at pace’
item.description: Dan Norris has been metro mayor for the West of England since 2021 and plans to serve until at least 2025. As mayor he leads the West of England Combined Authority which makes important decisions on transport, housing, the environment…

item.title: Could the River Frome reappear from underneath the Centre?
item.description: The post <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Could the River Frome reappear from underneath the Centre?<!-- raw HTML omitted --> appeared first on <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Bristol24/7<!-- raw HTML omitted -->.

item.title: “Music? Horrible.” David Yow’s Favourite Records
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Although he says he doesn’t listen to music, and that he’s not a musician, The Jesus Lizard’s David Yow nevertheless supplies a heartfelt Baker’s Dozen that ranges from Motörhead to Snoopy’s Christmas

item.title: Love Is The Transcendent Thing: Famous Interviewed
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Laviea Thomas meets Jack Merrett of the ironically-titled Famous to discuss their non-ironic elegies to the power of love. Featuring brand new video ‘What Are You Doing For The Rest Of Your Life?’ All portraits by Jack Lovekin

item.title: Pat Thomas – The Solar Model of Ibn Al-Shatir
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Pat Thomas

item.title: Britain’s first gay anthem? Why the UK’s pioneering LGBTQ+ protest band reunited
item.description: Written by members of the Gay Liberation Front in 1972, A Gay Song is a joyously defiant rallying cry. Artist Ian Giles explains why he persuaded its unruly creators to return to the studio

item.title: ‘Let them kick the crap out of the songs’: how we recreated the Beatles to make Backbeat
item.description: ‘I knew people who said John Lennon was angry, insecure and cruel in the early days. When I met Ian Hart, I saw he could provide that’

item.title: Listen: People Just Do Something – Fadumo Farah on Barton House, ACORN and a Holiday Inn mattress blockade
item.description: People Just Do Something is a relaxing and possibly enraging podcast about people who might self-identify as activists, untangling the means of effecting change in Bristol, broken Britain and beyond.

item.title: Coco & Clair Clair: Girl review – girlish singsong with sizzle and spark
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Nice Girl World)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->After years of lightweight pop, the duo are breaking new ground with their second full-length album<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->

item.title: Orrin Evans and the Captain Black Big Band: Walk a Mile in My Shoe review – perseverance and Philly pride
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Imani Records)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->Evans’ soulful and communal album explores his health condition with the help of A-list instrumentalists and vocal stars including Bilal and the legendary Lisa Fischer

item.title: ‘I’m intrigued by failure’: Kim Deal on death, addiction – and releasing her debut solo album at 63
item.description: Having weathered the losses of close family members and collaborator Steve Albini – and supported Olivia Rodrigo live at her request – the Breeders and Pixies star finds herself mooting mortality and legacy

item.title: The Cable’s campaign succeeds: more than 50% increase in membership income and a £40k bonus
item.description: The support of our many new, and existing, members has seen the Cable pass the membership target we’ve been working towards for a year, a week ahead of the deadline.

item.title: Huw Montague Rendall: Contemplation album review – young opera star justifies the buzz
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Montague Rendall/Opéra Orchestre Normandie Rouen/Glassberg<!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Erato)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->The debut album from the British baritone lives up to the hype, showcasing his velvet and nuanced singing with room to spare

item.title: Jason Schwartzman: ‘I was the kid driving around all the record stores buying all the Oasis singles’
item.description: The actor answers your questions on auditioning for Wes Anderson, his love of Britpop, his telepathic mother and never hearing back from Ringo Starr

item.title: Jon Hopkins: Ritual review | Alexis Petridis’s album of the week
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->(Domino)<!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted -->Originally written for an installation with mind-altering intentions, the producer’s seventh album is occasionally engaging but dissolves into drift

item.title: Darkness, drama and Daft Punk: the Weeknd’s best songs – ranked!
item.description: Ahead of Abel Tesfaye’s livestreamed concert in Brazil to launch his new era, we rate his path from cult mixtape star to pop icon

item.title: ‘We need to face them on the streets’: how trade unions are responding to the far-right threat
item.description: The scale of the recent far-right turnout in Bristol rattled many trade unionists. Now, an anti-racist taskforce is forming to organise opposition in the South West, but activists say unions must show they have migrant workers’ backs.

item.title: Vladimir, vapes and defending democracy: when the Cable met Pussy Riot in BS3
item.description: Celebrating the subversive, we spent an evening with the legendary Russian dissidents to get behind the balaclavas to discuss all things protest.

item.title: Council still hounding people with bailiffs after ‘ethical’ approach promise
item.description: The Cable has uncovered evidence Bristol City Council is referring thousands of council tax debts to enforcement agencies despite a stated policy to do so only as a last resort.

item.title: Education is the great liberator: the Bristol activists forging links with teachers in Palestine
item.description: Yasmeen Eshtaya is a Palestinian teacher whose life has been deeply affected by the brutal violence of the Israeli state. But she is committed to reconciliation and forming bonds through teaching Arabic – including to people in Bristol.

item.title: Under surveillance: how a man was recalled to prison after visiting a Bristol anarchist social centre
item.description: Toby Shone’s arrest by counter-terrorism police surveilling the BASE centre in Easton shows the state’s escalating clampdown on political dissent.

item.title: Fed up with the failings of mainstream media? Stand to be a Cable director
item.description: The Bristol Cable is looking for people to join our board of directors, who support and scrutinise the staff team’s work.
